title: Cambridge college faces resignations over decision to switch pension plans for staff
text:
A Cambridge college is facing a wave of resignations over its decision to switch pension plans for staff.

Trinity, one of Cambridge’s largest and wealthiest colleges, is facing a backlash from lecturers after formally withdrawing from the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS).

Proposed changes to the pension scheme saw thousands of academic staff go on strike last year amid a bitter dispute between university vice-Chancellors and academic staff.

Trinity College, which boasts six former British Prime Ministers among its alumni, pulled out of the scheme in May citing a “remote but existential risk” that it could be forced to help bail out the scheme in the event of a collapse of the UK’s higher education sector.

Following the move, hundreds of Cambridge academics signed a letter declaring that they will not do discretionary work for Trinity or supervise its students, meaning the college will struggle to offer several courses.

On Wednesday, Dr Arthur Asseraf, a lecturer in French history, said that he and “several others” were resigning from their fellowships at Trinity College to protest against their decision to leave the USS.

Announcing the move on Twitter, he said that the number of resignations the College now faces is “unprecedented”, adding that Trinity’s decision was “both selfish and unfounded”.
